title: Prefigurative Community Building (Part 35): Mycorrhizal Mutualism and Rewilding as Power With Coordination
summary: A guide to ecosystem restoration that mirrors forest coordination patterns, centering reciprocity with more-than-human life through Power With principles.

Community.summary: Build human communities that mirror mycorrhizal networks through reciprocal relationships and distributed coordination.

level0: Form small diverse circles of co-stewards interested in ecosystem restoration
Practice observing and listening to local ecosystems and land
Begin simple restoration activities like invasive species removal
level1: Establish consensus-based decision making that includes land as collaborator
Choose micro-sites for restoration using participatory design processes
Create shared infrastructure for restoration work and knowledge sharing
level2: Coordinate restoration across multiple sites using mycorrhizal network principles
Host skill-shares on fungal inoculation, native plant propagation, and restoration techniques
Build connections between restoration projects for mutual support
level3: Support formation of additional autonomous restoration circles
Create bioregional networks of ecosystem restoration projects
Advocate for policies that support community-controlled land healing

Knowledge.summary: Learn and share knowledge about ecological restoration, mycorrhizal relationships, and interspecies collaboration.

level0: Learn about mycorrhizal networks and forest communication systems
Study local ecology and traditional restoration practices
level1: Practice ecological observation and assessment techniques
Learn fungal cultivation and inoculation for ecosystem restoration
Document restoration processes and ecological changes over time
level2: Host workshops on mycorrhizal restoration and ecological partnership
Create resources about interspecies collaboration and ecosystem healing
Share knowledge with other restoration projects and researchers
level3: Develop comprehensive ecological restoration organizing toolkits
Research and document impacts of Power With vs Power Over restoration approaches
Train facilitators in other communities starting restoration projects

Narrative.summary: Challenge human supremacist narratives while promoting stories of interspecies collaboration and ecological partnership.

level0: Share stories about the intelligence and agency of forests and fungi
Practice seeing humans as part of rather than separate from ecosystems
Challenge narratives that position humans as managers of nature
level1: Document examples of successful interspecies collaboration and restoration
Challenge extractive approaches to conservation and land management
Share stories of ecological healing and regeneration
level2: Lead community conversations about interspecies relationships and ecological citizenship
Create media highlighting mycorrhizal principles in human organizing
Advocate for land management that centers ecological agency
level3: Contribute to cultural shift toward seeing humans as ecological partners
Develop and share analysis of restoration as interspecies collaboration
Support movements for rights of nature and ecological democracy
